content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

Here's a possible implementation of this function using regular expressions:

```julia
import Base.strip
function strip(str::AbstractString) 
    return replace(str, r"^[ \t]*\n?" => "")
end

function q_and_a_extractor(md)
    # Find the indices of the start and end of each question/answer section
    qstart = findfirst(md, "# Question")
    astart = findfirst(md, "# Answer")
    
    if (qstart === nothing || astart === nothing) 
        return ("", "")
    elseif qstart < astart
        # The answer is after the question, so we need to swap them
        qend = findnext(md, "\n", qstart)
        q = strip(md[qstart:qend])
        
        aend = findfirst(md, "# Answer")
        a = strip(md[aend:astart-1])
    else
        # The answer is before the question, so we keep them as they are
        qend = findnext(md, "\n", qstart)
        q = strip(md[qstart:qend])
        
        aend = findnext(md, "\n", astart)
        a = strip(md[astart:aend-1])
    end
    
    return (q, a)
end
```
This function first finds the indices of the start and ends of each question/answer section in the markdown text. If either section doesn't exist, it returns an empty tuple. 

It then extracts the text between these sections (after stripping any leading spaces or newlines) and returns them as a tuple.

Please note that this function assumes that there is only one question and answer in the markdown text, and that they are separated by at least one line of whitespace. If there may be more than one question/answer pair, or if they can be interspersed with other text, you'll need a different approach.
